assessments.task_description:
This is a secure assessment, designed to ensure confidence that the work reflects the student’s own learning.

In this assessment, students should demonstrate their understanding of the research topic, relevant literature, and the proposed methods for their research project to their supervisor(s). This assessment is also intended to provide timely feedback on the research proposal, to ensure the supervisor(s) and student agree on the research plan and timeline. The review consists of two parts:

(1)   Project proposal

Students must submit a written proposal to their supervisor(s) before the meeting. This written proposal is not graded; therefore it can be in any format, any length, and can be a draft (discuss with research supervisors on their expectations). Writing the proposal is a way to get students prepared for the review meeting. The written proposal can also form part of the final report.

As a guide (i.e. not a requirment), the proposal should be under 2,000 words (excluding references) and include:

a.     the background to the intended research;

b.     the research question, aims and objectives;

c.     the research methods;

d.     the expected outcomes;

e.     the significance of the research and its contribution to new knowledge;

f.       the timeline of the research

(2)   Review meeting held between weeks 4 and 6

The meeting should include:

a.     Student’s introduction and a presentation of their progress to date (suggested length: 5-10mins)

b.     A Q&A session for supervisor(s) to assess the student’s understanding of the topic, e.g. identifying the research gap(s), the appropriateness and limitations of methods, explaining the significance of the research, and outlining the next steps

c.     Feedback from the supervisor(s) on the proposal and discussion of any concerns

The supervisor(s) will mark the student’s performance in the review meeting, based on their understanding of the project. The review meeting must be recorded, and a link of the recording should be submitted to Blackboard as proof of assessment completion. The meeting may be held online or in person (an in-person meeting can be recorded using a webcam/phone). The supervisor(s) may require the student to amend the proposal following the review.

Students are responsible for organising the review meeting, recording the meeting, and completing a short form on Blackboard following the meeting. Students should start planning for the review early in the course, e.g. discuss with the supervisor on the meeting timing and their expectations.

Submission guide: Students are to complete a short form on Blackboard following the meeting. The form includes a link (URL) to the recorded meeting. This should be completed and submitted by the due date. Late penalties apply.

(As per UQ policy, the recording must be retained for at least one year after the release of final grades for potential re-marking).

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
This is a secured assessment, designed to ensure confidence that the work reflects the student’s own learning. Students can fail this assessment if they are uncontactable by their supervisor(s) for extended periods without reason.

The mark for research performance will be based on the supervisor's observations during the project, through regular communications, which may include in-person or online meetings, and email communications. The marking criteria include the student’s inquiry skills, discipline-specific skills, and professionalism. Examples of inquiry skills include, but are not limited to, gathering relevant scientific information using databases and library and the internet, extracting pertinent information from scientific papers, and participating in discussions with the supervisor and/or research group. Discipline-specific skills include, but are not limited to, generating data, collecting samples, and analysing data. Students are expected to consult with their supervisor about the skills required for their project.
assessments.submission_guidelines: No submittable items for students. Supervisor to mark the student's research performance at the end of the semester.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
